member.name: T:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus
member.summary: Reports the status of sending an Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) echo message to a computer.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.BadDestination
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the destination IP address cannot receive ICMP echo requests or should never appear in the destination address field of any IP datagram. For example, calling and specifying IP address "000.0.0.0" returns this status.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.BadHeader
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the header is invalid.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.BadOption
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because it contains an invalid option.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.BadRoute
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because there is no valid route between the source and destination computers.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.DestinationHostUnreachable
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the destination computer is not reachable.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.DestinationNetworkUnreachable
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the network that contains the destination computer is not reachable.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.DestinationPortUnreachable
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the port on the destination computer is not available.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.DestinationProhibited
member.summary: The ICMPv6 echo request failed because contact with the destination computer is administratively prohibited. This value applies only to IPv6.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.DestinationProtocolUnreachable
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the destination computer that is specified in an ICMP echo message is not reachable, because it does not support the packet's protocol. This value applies only to IPv4. This value is described in IETF RFC 1812 as Communication Administratively Prohibited.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.DestinationScopeMismatch
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the source address and destination address that are specified in an ICMP echo message are not in the same scope. This is typically caused by a router forwarding a packet using an interface that is outside the scope of the source address. Address scopes (link-local, site-local, and global scope) determine where on the network an address is valid.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.DestinationUnreachable
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the destination computer that is specified in an ICMP echo message is not reachable; the exact cause of problem is unknown.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.HardwareError
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because of a hardware error.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.IcmpError
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because of an ICMP protocol error.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.NoResources
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because of insufficient network resources.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.PacketTooBig
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the packet containing the request is larger than the maximum transmission unit (MTU) of a node (router or gateway) located between the source and destination. The MTU defines the maximum size of a transmittable packet.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.ParameterProblem
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because a node (router or gateway) encountered problems while processing the packet header. This is the status if, for example, the header contains invalid field data or an unrecognized option.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.SourceQuench
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the packet was discarded. This occurs when the source computer's output queue has insufficient storage space, or when packets arrive at the destination too quickly to be processed.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.Success
member.summary: The ICMP echo request succeeded; an ICMP echo reply was received. When you get this status code, the other properties contain valid data.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.TimedOut
member.summary: The ICMP echo Reply was not received within the allotted time. The default time allowed for replies is 5 seconds. You can change this value using the or methods that take a parameter.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.TimeExceeded
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because its Time to Live (TTL) value reached zero, causing the forwarding node (router or gateway) to discard the packet.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.TtlExpired
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because its Time to Live (TTL) value reached zero, causing the forwarding node (router or gateway) to discard the packet.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.TtlReassemblyTimeExceeded
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the packet was divided into fragments for transmission and all of the fragments were not received within the time allotted for reassembly. RFC 2460 specifies 60 seconds as the time limit within which all packet fragments must be received.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.Unknown
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed for an unknown reason.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.UnrecognizedNextHeader
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the Next Header field does not contain a recognized value. The Next Header field indicates the extension header type (if present) or the protocol above the IP layer, for example, TCP or UDP.
